title: Trail Mix-Up
plot_outline: During a picnic, Baby Herman follows a beaver into a perilous sawmill - with Roger Rabbit in frantic pursuit.
keywords: [u'beaver', u'sawmill', u'roger-rabbit', u'baby', u'animal-protagonist', u'anthropomorphic-animal', u'anthropomorphic-rabbit', u'anthropomorphism', u'polka-dot-underwear', u'half-dressed-animal', u'water-slide', u'boulder', u'beehive', u'caterpillar', u'white-animal', u'rabbit-feet', u'feet', u'animal-feet', u'legs', u'lifting-male-in-air', u'surrealism', u'cartoon-rabbit', u'cartoon-dog', u'lifting-someone-into-the-air', u'basset-hound', u'droopy', u'dog', u'part-live-action', u'bee', u'log-flume', u'sequel', u'waterfall', u'maroon-cartoon', u'bear', u'mount-rushmore', u'camping', u'geyser', u'surprise-ending']
taglines: [u"It looks like we don't have any Taglines for this title yet."]
trivia: [u'At one point the log Roger and Baby Herman are riding has a bumper sticker that reads "We Visited Splash Mountain".', u"As Roger runs along the top of the logs, there is a whip-pan shot where the camera passes by a poster for 'Rigid Tools' with a woman seductively straddling a saw, styled in cheescake 1940s fashion. This poster became the bane of Disney for several years and resulted in the laserdisc version of this short getting recalled and re-issued minus the now digitally-erased poster. Many VHS editions of the short still contain the full version, though it is actually only viewable on screen for about 4 frames.", u"As Roger and Baby Herman ride past the camera at the beginning of the flume ride, Baby Herman's eyes have Mickey Mouse heads for a few frames; then as Roger rides past, his eyes have skulls for the same amount of time.", u'As Roger spits the bees out of his mouth, they have various Disney character heads like Mickey Mouse, Genie from Aladdin (1992), Evinrude from Pelastuspartio Bernard ja Bianca (1977), and Tinker Bell from Peter Pan (1953).', u'Was released theatrically with A Far Off Place (1993).', u"Animators were told to remove the buttons on the pockets of Jessica's Park Ranger uniform in her close-up when she leans into the camera because they were too anatomically suggestive. (They appear in the longs shots).", u'When Roger fumigates his campsite, the bug spray he uses is labeled "Mink-Off" - a reference to producer Rob Minkoff.', u'This animated short can be found on the Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988) Vista Series DVD, released in 2003.', u"Originally there were going to be four more Roger Rabbit shorts to be made after this one. The first one was Hare In My Soup which was going to be released with Toy Story (1995)_, and the last three were called Clean and Oppressed, Beach Blanket Bay and Bronco Bustin' Bunny. However they all ended up being canceled due to Steven Speilberg_'s ownership stake of not liking the second short Roller Coaster Rabbit (1990)_ appear with Dick Tracy (1990)_ and not Arachnophobia (1990)_ which his company Amblin Entertainment made with Disney."]
release_dates: [u'USA::12 March 1993', u'UK::13 August 1993', u'Ireland::20 August 1993', u'Germany::26 August 1993', u'Colombia::26 November 1993', u'UK::22 October 1999 (re-release)']

title: Tiny Toon Adventures
plot_outline: The adventures of a new generation of Warner Bros. Looney Tunes characters.
keywords: [u'older-actors-younger-roles', u'coyote', u'duck', u'canary', u'cult-favorite', u'half-dressed-cartoon-animal', u'anthropomorphism', u'anthropomorphic-animal', u'young-version-of-character', u'tasmanian-devil', u'gremlin', u'rabbit', u'imagination', u'breaking-the-fourth-wall', u'hollywood', u'spoof', u'self-referential', u'acme-brand']
taglines: [u"They're Tiny. They're Toony. They're All A Little Looney! And They're All From The Emmy Nominated Series. (USA DVD Season 1 - Volume 1)", u"Laughs, Gags, Anvils! More of the Acme of the Cartoon Fun From the Emmy-Winning' First Season! (USA DVD Season 1 - Volume 2)", u'Add A Little Looney and a Lotta Fun To Your Collection! (USA DVD Volume 3)', u'Add Even More Laughs To Your Looney Library! (USA DVD Volume 4)']
trivia: [u"Wackyland, the bizarre world that Gogo-Dodo comes from, wasn't created for this show; it actually first appeared in a little known Looney Tunes short named _Porky in Wackyland_ (1938), which also featured a dodo that looked and acted exactly like Gogo Dodo from this series.", u'In the episode "Never Too Late To Loon", Acme Acres is found to be located in Arkansas.', u'The episode "Tiny Toon Adventures" (1990) {Buster and Babs Go Hawaiian (#2.8)} was co-written by 3 then-teenage girls (Renee Carter, Sarah Creef, and Amy Crosby) , who just happened to be fans of the series.', u'Tiny Toons was originally planned to be a feature length film for theatrical release, but was later changed to a TV series.', u'Each episode contained 25,000 animation cels, which was more than double the industry standard at the time of 10,000. This allowed the characters to move more fluidly.', u'Tiny Toons won the Daytime Emmy for Outstanding Animated Program three straight years from 1991-1993.', u'Danny Cooksey, who voiced Montana Max, was the only cast member at the time who was not an adult.', u'This was the first animated series produced by Steven Spielberg and Warner Brothers Animation.', u'The series had two spin-offs, The Plucky Duck Show (1992) and Pinky, Elmyra & the Brain (1998).', u'Dennis "Quozl" Falk, was an actual overly-obsessed fan the production team encountered while working on Tiny Toon Adventures (1990). He was a stalker who sent Tress MacNeille disturbing letters which caused her to fear for life and cancel any convention appearances she was planning to make around where he lives.', u"Fifi Le Fume's perfume of choice is Le Stink.", u'The character of Ralph the Warner Bros. studio security guard later appeared as a regular character on another Warner Bros. animated series, Animaniacs (1993).', u'Voice Director Andrea Romano auditioned over 1,200 actors for the series.', u'Writer Paul Dini said the original idea for Tiny Toons came from then Warner Brothers President Terry Semel, who said he wanted to inject new life into the animation department.', u'This is the only animated series produced by Steven Spielberg in which he provided his own voice for a guest appearance. For all subsequent cameos in other series, his voice was impersonated by Frank Welker.', u'The nonsensical word "narf" which was made famous by Pinky on Animaniacs (1993) made its first appearance in the secret message in the credits of the episode Tiny Toon Adventures: You Asked for It: Part 1 (1990). The message: "Guy Who Says "Narf" - Eddie Fitzgerald"', u"A soundtrack entitled 'Tiny Toons Sing' was released in 1992 and was available on CD and Audio Cassette.", u"Warner Bros. released seven VHS tapes of Tiny Toon Adventures from 1993 to 1996. They are: The Best of Buster and Babs (released March 24, 1993, containing the episodes: 'Prom-ise Her Anything' and 'Thirteensomething').Tiny Toon Music Television (released March 24, 1993 containing the episodes: 'Tiny Toon Music Television' and 'Toon TV').Tiny Toons in Two-Tone Town (released March 24, 1993 containing the episodes: 'Two-Tone Town' and 'Fields of Honey').Fiendishly Funny Adventures (released December 4, 1994 containing the episodes: 'Duck in the Dark', 'Little Cake of Horrors', 'Night of the Living Pets' and 'Hare-Raising Night').BIG Adventures (released July 11, 1995 containing the episodes: 'Journey to the Center of Acme Acres' and 'A Ditch in Time').Island Adventures (released July 11, 1995 containing the episodes: 'No Toon is an Island' and 'Buster and Babs Go Hawaiian').It's a Wonderful Christmas Special (released 1996 containing 'It's A Wonderful Tiny Toons Christmas Special').", u"Buster and Babs each represent a different aspect of Bugs Bunny's character. Buster represents his sarcastic, wisecracking side while Babs is his more off-the-wall, wild side.", u'According to producer Tom Ruegger, the famous Warner Bros. animator Chuck Jones was not too keen on the show featuring "junior versions" of characters he\'d created. Because of this, characters like Calamity Coyote and Little Beeper (based respectively on Wile E. Coyote and Roadrunner) were used sparingly throughout the show, and Barky Marky (based on Marc Antony) became the subject of a running gag about his lack of appearances.', u'In one episode, where Babs performs a plethora of impersonations, she impersonates Marge, Bart, and Maggie Simpson. Tress MacNeille, who provided the voice of Babs, is a regular on The Simpsons (1989).', u"The majority of the characters are based on classic Looney Tunes stars. Including more minor characters like Beaky Buzzard and Sniffles the Mouse (Concord Condor and Li'l Sneezer respectively).", u'According to Paul Dini, Danny Cooksey was good as Montana Max because he could do a "tremendous mean voice."']
release_dates: [u'USA::14 September 1990', u'Australia::26 March 1991', u'Brazil::8 April 1991', u'UK::14 September 1991', u'Spain::10 November 1991', u'Canada::24 March 1993 (video premiere)']

title: The Plucky Duck Show
plot_outline: A spin-off of the Tiny Toons animated series featuring junior egomaniac Plucky Duck. With the help of his sidekick...

trivia: [u'With the exception of the premiere episode "The Return of Batduck" and the short "Wait \'Til Your Father Gets Even", this show was made up entirely of recycled Plucky Duck cartoons from older episodes of Tiny Toon Adventures (1990). "The Return of Batduck" aired in reruns of Tiny Toons, but it was edited in order to fit in the regular Tiny Toon opening and ending. "Wait \'Til Your Father Gets Even" eventually aired as part of the episode "Toons From the Crypt" when the show re-ran on Nickelodeon.']
release_dates: [u'USA::19 September 1992']

plot_outline: Term-time ends at Acme Looniversity and the Tiny Toon characters look forward to a summer filled with fun...

taglines: [u'Spend Your Vacation With Tiny Toons! (USA DVD)', u"All-new fun with everyone's favourite little stars! (Australia VHS)", u"All-new fun with everyone's favorite little stars! (USA VHS)"]
trivia: [u'The title of this film was originally How I Spent My Summer Vacation, but Warner Bros. shortened it so it would fit on the video cover.', u'When Buster and Babs are falling after going over the waterfall Buster grabs onto Babs and says "I\'ve got you!" to which she responds "But whose got you?". These are the same lines spoken (respectively) by Christopher Reeve and Margot Kidder from the film Superman (1978) when Lois Lane falls from the top of the Daily Planet building and is caught by Superman in mid-air. At this moment Superman flies up to catch Buster and Babs, responding to her question with "I do, kids!"', u'When Babs goes over the waterfall she lands in a pool and goes under water to find a group of fish, crustaceans and a mermaid playing instruments and singing a tune (seemingly) called "Beneath The Ocean"; an obvious parody of the famous song "Under The Sea" from The Little Mermaid (1989). Babs immediately utters "Whoops. Wrong Cartoon"', u'The first animated feature to be released direct-to-video in the U.S.', u'The THUD sound system promo during the theater scene is a parody of Lucasfilm\'s famous THX promos, the slogan of which is "The Audience is Listening". The announcer in this says "The Audience is Now Deaf."', u'While it did not state the revenue of the film, the Toronto Star stated that the film sold so well that Warner Bros. decided to release videos of Tiny Toon Adventures episodes.', u'This film marks the first time the Road Runner gets ran over.', u'On February 6, 1993, How I Spent My Vacation had been on the "Top Kid Video" list for 41 weeks.', u'Was the only Tiny Toon Adventures media to be released on Laserdisc format.', u"'Happy World Land' is a parody of Disneyland.", u"The film was released on DVD by Warner Bros 20 years after it's VHS release.", u"The hitchhiker that Hampton's parent's pick up is a spoof of both Letherface from 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre', Jason Voorhees from 'Friday the 13th' and John Ryder from 'The Hitcher'.", u'The movie that Fowlmouth, Shirley, Fifi and Johnny see is called Skunknophobia which is a parody of the 1990 film, Arachnophobia.', u'This film marks the first time Road Runner has got ran over.', u'The VHS release was the was one of the highest selling videos in the United States; on the Billboard charts. It ranked ranked 12th in sales in April 1992.', u'In May 1992, the film rose to 9th in video sales.', u'On July 18, 1992, the film had been on Billboard Magazine\'s 40 "Top Video Sales" for 16 weeks.', u'On June 27, 1992, the film was ranked the 5th highest on Billboard\'s "Top Kid Video".', u'The movie was split into four episodes for syndication, with a voiceover briefly recapping the events in each episode.', u"Tiny Toon Adventures: How I Spent My Vacation aired on The Hub's Family Movie Event on August 23 at 8:00-5:00 PM eastern and pacific time.", u"The rides at HappyWorldLand are: The Tooth FerryHappy Go PukeyHappy FeetThe GargleThe Happy CrasherThe Happy CentrifugeSlap Happy FunThe Stairway to HeavenThe Bullet Train to HeckUnfortunately, Plucky and Hampton don't get to go on any of them.", u"Buster has a picture on his locker of Rover, his dinosaur pet from the Tiny Toon Adventures episode 'Rock 'N' Roar' in season 1.", u"Sorrell Booke's last film.", u'The retail price of the USA DVD was $19.97.', u'Wade Pig was voiced by Jonathan Winters in this film, whereas in the series he was voiced by Joe Alaskey.', u'The film was screened once in an actual theater. The catch is, it was an internal theater on the Warner Bros. Studios lot.', u'It has been released on VHS, Laserdisc, and DVD.', u"The animal park that Elmyra's family goes to is a spoof of Six Flags Wild Safari animal park.", u'The retail price of the USA Laserdisc was $24.98.', u"The car that Hamton's parents own is based upon a 1955-1957 Chevrolet Bel Air sedan.", u"The car that Elmyra's parents own is a fictional Volvo station wagon.", u'The song "Waiting for the Clock to Strike Three" is set to a piano composition entitled "Spinning Song" by Albert Ellmenreich.', u'The USA DVD release from Warner Bros includes the original English audio track as well as a Spanish and Portuguese audio track.']
release_dates: [u'Germany::1992', u'Brazil::11 March 1992', u'Canada::11 March 1992', u'USA::11 March 1992', u'Hungary::1994', u'France::June 1994', u'UK::1 August 1994']

title: A Wish for Wings That Work
plot_outline: Opus the Penguin struggles to achieve his seemingly impossible dream to be able to fly.
keywords: [u'penguin', u'christmas', u'cat', u'letter-to-santa-claus', u'animal-protagonist', u"based-on-children's-book", u'based-on-comic-strip', u'1930s', u'cartoon-animal', u'talking-cat', u'talking-animal', u'cartoon-duck', u'tabby', u'duck', u'flightless-bird', u'1990s', u'cartoon-pig', u'pig', u'balloon', u'anthropomorphic-cat', u'pig-feet', u'kiwi-feet', u'kiwi', u'anthropomorphic-animal', u'auk-feet', u'great-auk', u'auk', u'bird-feet', u'cat-feet', u'animal-feet', u'feet', u'cartoon-cat', u'six-word-title', u'santa-claus', u'satire', u'based-on-comic', u'based-on-book']
taglines: [u"It looks like we don't have any Taglines for this title yet."]
trivia: [u'Based on a children\'s book which featured characters from the comic strips "Bloom County" and "Outland". All were written and drawn by Berkley Breathed.', u'Berkeley Breathed was exceptionally displeased with the quality of the final product. In an exchange published in the Washington Post he said to a person trying to find the VHS or DVD version, "Hopefully [you will find it] in the rubbish pail. We can do better than that and we will with an eventual Opus film...but I\'m glad you enjoyed it. I presume your family was on speed when they watched it. I would imagine it helps."', u"During the production of Hook (1991), executive producer Steven Spielberg decided to utilize lead actors Robin Williams (The Kiwi) and Dustin Hoffman (The Cockroach) to record (in what little time he had) their voice-over work in a small studio. This is why both A-list stars were available for this animated special. It is also the reason why the quality of their voice recordings isn't as clear as the rest of the cast.", u'The movie cut away of Opus trying to fly a DC-3 is referenced to a poster on his bedroom wall.', u"The cross-dressing cockroach is voiced by an uncredited Dustin Hoffman. One of Hoffman's most famous films was 'Tootsie' in which he played a cross dresser.", u"The live action footage from Opus' nightmare is from 'Lost Horizon.'", u'The "support group" scene is adapted from an installment of the comic strip \'Outland.\' The major difference being that, in the strip, Opus is leading the group, rather than Ronald Ann.']
release_dates: [u'USA::18 December 1991']

title: An American Tail: Fievel Goes West
plot_outline: A family of Emigre mice decide to move out to the west, unaware that they are falling into a trap perpetrated by a smooth talking cat.
keywords: [u'cat', u'mirage', u'spider', u'dog', u'gang-leader', u'gang-that-lives-together', u'outlaw-gang', u'actor', u'dancer', u'singer', u'cleavage', u'balladeer', u'singer-offscreen', u'friends-who-live-together', u'giant-mousetrap', u'colon-in-title', u'six-word-title', u'street-shootout', u'19th-century', u'anthropomorphic-mouse', u'1890s', u'gun-shot-out-of-hand', u'disarming-someone', u'pistol', u'mild-violence', u'quick-draw', u'sheriff', u'fantasy-sequence', u'gunfight', u'gun-battle', u'shootout', u'opening-action-scene', u'dual-wield', u'wild-west', u'talking-animal', u'animal-name-in-title', u'anthropomorphism', u'anthropomorphic-animal', u'old-west', u'cowboy', u'american-tail', u'tumbleweed', u'train', u'record-player', u'slingshot', u'cat-versus-mouse', u'monument-valley', u'mouse', u'sequel', u'pitchfork', u'character-name-in-title']
taglines: [u"Look out pardners, there's a new mouse in town!"]
trivia: [u"This was James Stewart's final film before his death on July 2, 1997 at the age of 89.", u'John Cleese turned down the role of Cogsworth in Beauty and the Beast (1991) to play Cat R. Waul in this film.', u'When Fievel is riding on the tumbleweed, the "Theme from Rawhide" is being played in the background. It is the version sung by John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd from The Blues Brothers (1980) which features a cameo appearance by Steven Spielberg in it.', u"Though undetected for decades, there is a penis doodle hidden in the film. It's visible in the DVD and VHS versions. At the 46:20 mark of the film, while Fievel's sister is singing Dreams to Dream, a penis doodle appear's in front of her face for one frame.", u"Steven Spielberg personally came to James Stewart's sound booth to direct him. He is uncredited as a voice-over director, though.", u'"Dreams To Dream" was originally recorded by C\xe9line Dion, but the producers favored Linda Ronstadt, who sang the theme song, "Somewhere Out There", in An American Tail (1986).', u'Owing to creative differences, Don Bluth parted ways with Steven Spielberg, with whom he had directed the original An American Tail (1986), as well as the first of 13 Land Before Time films. With no Bluth in sight for the sequel, Spielberg instead relied on Phil Nibbelink, a former Disney animator, and Simon Wells, the grandson of science-fiction author H.G. Wells, to direct the project.', u'This film was released on the same day (November 22, 1991) as the Walt Disney animated film Beauty and the Beast (1991).', u'In An American Tail (1986), Papa Mousekewiz is a tailor, according to the sign over the front door of his house as seen during "Somewhere Out There". In this movie, however, he is a violin maker.', u'The song "Dreams to Dream" is based on a theme used in An American Tail (1986). It is heard during Bridget\'s speech in the market, as well as at the end of the Orphan Alley sequence, as the camera pulls back on the orphaned mice sleeping in the rain.', u'It is the sole theatrical sequel to An American Tail (1986), and was followed at the end of the 1990s by another two direct-to-video sequels, both of which took place chronologically before this film.', u'In addition to a new voice actress, the character of Tanya was heavily redesigned as well. Tiger had minor changes, as does Yasha (the baby), and Fievel looks slightly different.', u'Several of the storefronts and signs in Green River are named for members of the crew: "Ph. Nibbelink Eyeglasses" and "Wells\' Dentistry" (directors Phil Nibbelink and Simon Wells); "P. Rappas Clothing", "Dunnet\'s Bread and Cakes", and "Saint Brendan Holy Chapel" (layout artists Panagiotis Rappas, Dave Dunnet, and Brendan Houghton); and "Woodbyrne Knickers & Garters" (for production manager Cynthia Henrich-Woodbyrne). In addition, one fa\xe7ade in the "Way Out West" sequence reads "Mardegan" (for layout artist Giorgio Mardegan).', u'One of the flyers in Miss Kitty\'s dressing room lists scene planner Harald Kraut as the manager of the "Pine Street Theatre."', u"Celine Dion was originally going to sing Dreams to Dream and even recorded a demo for Steven Spielberg. Unfortunately, it was rejected which prompted Dion to be terminated. Devastated by this, Celine Dion would later went on to record Beauty and the Beast with Peabo Bryson after listening to Angela Lansbury's rendition, also released on the same year as this film. Dion would later reunite with Will Jennings and James Horner on the 1997 hit 'My Heart Will Go On' from Titanic.", u'One view of the cats\' mousetrap (visible right before Fievel dispatches them at the end) displays a nameplate, facing upside-down, which reads "Made in Acton, London"; this was the location of the Amblimation studio where the film was produced.', u'Don Bluth and his animation studio, Sullivan Bluth Studios, were originally going to make the film, as they had done with An American Tail (1986). Universal agreed, under the condition that it would cost no more than $9.6 million, similar to the budget of the first film, but $3 million less than The Land Before Time (1988), which Bluth was already directing for them. Faced with the prospect of having to lay off employees at his studio, Bluth declined the job, and parted ways with Universal after finishing their commitment with "The Land Before Time." Ironically, the film was made for roughly $25 million, twice as much as "Land" had cost to make.', u'Bridget and Tony (along with their baby) make two unspoken cameos in the film. The first is during the cat attack and the second is when the mice first settle in the West.', u'Originally, another voice actress was going to play Tanya. However, after auditioning and singing the song "Dreams to Dream" Steven Spielbergdecided to cast Cathy Cavadini as both Tanya\'s speaking and singing voice. The unknown actress\' dialogue was removed from the film and Cathy re-dubbed all the lines.', u"Miss Kitty, Tiger's love interest, was voiced by Amy Irving, who was previously married to Spielberg and this film was released in 1991, the year he married Kate Capshaw, who had worked with him on Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984).", u"The only sequel to one of Don Bluth's films to release Theatrically. The other sequels simply were released Straight-to-Video/DVD.", u"The only Animated Sequel distributed by Universal to release Theatrically up until Illumination's Despicable Me 2 (2013) 22 years later.", u'During the song "Dreams to Dream", a book is shown with a scene from the Beauty and the Beast fairytale. Disney released their animated version of Beauty and the Beast on the same day as "An American tail: Fievel Goes West".']

taglines: [u'The Bowden family has moved to New Essex.', u'He learned to read.', u"There is nothing in the dark that isn't there in the light. Except fear.", u"Sam Bowden has always provided for his family's future. But the past is coming back to haunt them."]
trivia: [u"The thick accent Robert De Niro used to play Max Cady reportedly gave Martin Scorsese the creeps. As a joke, De Niro would call Scorsese's house, leaving voicemails as Cady.", u'Robert De Niro was tattooed with vegetable dyes, which fade after a few months.', u'The scene in the high school auditorium was totally ad-libbed by Robert De Niro and Juliette Lewis, and done on the first take.', u'Martin Scorsese read the original script three times while making Goodfellas (1990) and hated it each time because of how the Bowdens were a happy family and wanted them to be miserable.', u'Robert De Niro did a lot of working out several months before the movie and during the shoot to make him the muscular Max Cady, reportedly taking his body fat down to only 3%.', u'Robert De Niro researched sexual predator crimes for the part and suggested the scene where his character bites the victim.', u'Robert De Niro paid a dentist $5,000 to make his teeth look suitably bad for the role of Max Cady. After filming, he paid $20,000 to have them fixed.', u"Director Martin Scorsese's first choice for the role of Bowden was Harrison Ford. He had Robert De Niro call Ford to try convincing him to take the part.", u'Drew Barrymore tested for the role of Danielle Bowden but failed the audition. She later said she had "acted all over the place and it was just the biggest disaster of my life."', u"This was Gregory Peck's final appearance in a theatrical film release before his death on June 12, 2003 at the age of 87.", u"Robert De Niro's Cady accent came from an earlier role where he played a southerner. To prepare for the role, De Niro took excerpts of the script and a tape recorder into southern towns and would ask locals to read the lines into the tape.", u'Steven Spielberg was originally set to direct. He later recommended Martin Scorsese for the job and personally called the director, letting him know that this was a commercial film that had potential to be a hit, which would exercise more power for Scorsese to make his films.', u'Originally in the scene where Cady puts handcuffs on Lori, she was supposed to start freaking out, Illeana Douglas was the one who came up with the idea of having her character laughing and trying to play along instead.', u'The auditorium scene was originally scripted as a chase scene, but Martin Scorsese wanted it to be a seduction.', u'Unlike Nick Nolte and Robert De Niro, Gregory Peck and Robert Mitchum did not get along well with each other off screen while filming Cape Fear (1962) years prior. Notably, despite their small roles in the remake, Peck and Mitchum do not appear in any scenes together.', u'Juliette Lewis developed a crush on Robert De Niro during the scene in the drama class.', u'The scene between Robert De Niro and Juliette Lewis in the school was shot in three takes, but the first one was used in final productions.', u'In the original script, Leigh only met Max Cady at the end. Jessica Lange suggested the scene where they talk outside her house be added to the script, because she felt there should be a meeting between the two before the climax.', u"Gregory Peck, who starred in Cape Fear (1962), appears as Cady's lawyer. Robert Mitchum played Max Cady in the 1962 version, and appears as Lieutenant Elgart. Martin Balsam played Mark Dutton in the 1962 version and the judge in this version.", u"The score by Elmer Bernstein is not only an arrangement of Bernard Herrmann's original Cape Fear (1962) score, but also includes parts of Herrmann's unused score for Torn Curtain (1966).", u'Both Robert De Niro and Nick Nolte had to alter their physiques for the film because the 6\'0", bulky, Nolte is clearly larger than the 5\'9", slimmer De Niro. Nolte slimmed down, losing a good deal of weight, while shooting the film and De Niro bulked up his muscles considerably until De Niro could be seen as Nolte\'s physical superior. Interestingly the original Sam Bowden (Gregory Peck 6\'3" at his peak) was also slightly taller than the original Max Cady (Robert Mitchum 6\'1" at his peak).', u'Reese Witherspoon auditioned for the role of Danielle Bowden.', u'The climax was filmed inside a 90-foot water-tank on a soundstage. It took four weeks to shoot.', u'When Steven Spielberg was attached to direct he had plans on casting Bill Murray as Max Cady.', u'Christina Applegate did an audition for the role of Danielle, but had to turn down the part due to conflicts from Married with Children (1986) producer Ron Leavitt.', u"Alyssa Milano was offered the role of Danielle but had to turn down the role, due to pressure from fellow Who's the Boss? (1984) cast member Tony Danza.", u'The climactic scene out in the swamp was filmed in John U. Lloyd State Park, in the middle of a mangrove swamp. A tropical depression set over the set for four days, so the film crew had to wait for the storm to stop so that they could make their own rain.', u"In the auditorium scene between Robert De Niro and Juliette Lewis, it was De Niro's idea to put his thumb in her mouth.", u"Robert De Niro helped costume designer Rita Ryack choose Cady's clothing.", u'It took a year to convince Martin Scorsese to make this movie.', u'Robert De Niro played scenes with Kevin Kline and Phoebe Cates in the Sam and Danielle roles for Martin Scorsese when De Niro was trying to interest him in directing the film.', u'George C. Scott was originally supposed to play the Lieutenant role. But because of health problems he dropped out a few days before filming and Robert Mitchum was brought in.', u"For the first time in Martin Scorsese's career, he allowed the screenwriter, Wesley Strick, on the set during filming.", u"Martin Scorsese wanted the Bowdens' house surrounded by oak trees, covered by hanging tufts of Spanish moss. He wanted it so it looked like a sunny oasis by day, and isolating by night. Therefore, it would make a perfect dark cover for Cady.", u"Robert De Niro and Illeana Douglas's scenes were improvised.", u'Filmed in 17 weeks in South Florida.', u'During the opening sequence Max Cady is seen working out in his cell and the camera pans over his jail time reading material. One of the books featured is The Cell Within by Jake Manning. This is not a published work and only exists as part of a Miami Vice (1984) storyline. In Miami Vice: The Cell Within (1989), Tubbs is tormented and imprisoned by the author Jake Manning, an ex-con he helped convict years before.', u'The scene where Robert De Niro sits on the brick wall, he actually sits in front of a blue screen where the fireworks were added later in production.', u'Jennifer Connelly and Winona Ryder both turned down the role of Danielle.', u'Martin Scorsese directed the film as part of a two picture deal with Universal Studio because of their help and support with the release of The Last Temptation of Christ (1988). The other picture in the deal was Casino (1995).', u'Gregory Peck completed filming his cameo scenes in one day.', u"Robert Richardson auditioned for the position of cinematographer but lost out to Britain's Freddie Francis. Martin Scorsese, a staunch admirer of Richardson's work with his former NYU student Oliver Stone, remembered Richardson when he was preparing to direct Casino (1995).", u"Robert Mitchum feared in comparing his character of Max Cady to Robert De Niro's portrayal in the film. He had never seen either movies.", u"The music that is heard at the climax of the movie was a piece of music that Bernard Herrmann had written for Alfred Hitchcock's Torn Curtain (1966), but that piece of music was never used. Elmer Bernstein had always liked that original score and he asked Martin Scorsese if it could be used in the film.", u'Robert Redford was also considered for the role of Sam Bowden.', u'The ice cream parlor scene was shot in the first week of production where the owners complained for the first three days that they were losing business.', u'This was Amblin Entertainment\'s first "R" rated film.', u'The script went through 24 drafts.', u"Diane Keaton met with Martin Scorsese and Robert De Niro to discuss playing the role of Leigh Bowden, but didn't win the part.", u'Nicole Kidman lobbied for the role of Danielle, but Martin Scorsese wanted a younger actress.', u'Illeana Douglas based her performance as Lori Davis on Jennifer Levin, who was murdered in 1986 in Central Park by Robert Chambers (whom the press dubbed the "Preppy Murderer").', u'This is the first film that Martin Scorsese uses optical FX.', u'The music video that Danielle watches to avoid her parents\' argument is Jane\'s Addiction\'s "Been Caught Stealing."', u'This was the first film Martin Scorsese shot in the wider 2.39:1 aspect ratio, as opposed to the taller 1.85:1 ratio in which he had filmed all his previous works (excluding New York, New York (1977), which was shot in 1.66:1).', u'The film cast includes four Oscar winners: Robert De Niro, Jessica Lange, Martin Balsam, Gregory Peck; and three Oscar nominees: Nick Nolte, Robert Mitchum and Juliette Lewis.', u"Former wrestler Dan Spivey's short-lived 1995 WWE gimmick Waylon Mercy was based on Max Cady. Windham Rotunda's WWE gimmick Bray Wyatt has elements of Waylon Mercy and thus is influenced by Max Cady by default.", u'There is an iconic shooting star scene; an apparent nod to Steven Spielberg.', u'Martin Scorsese had also wanted Telly Savalas to return from the original cast.', u'Sarah Jessica Parker was originally cast as Danielle.', u'Brad Dourif was considered to play Max Cady.', u'Lori, talking with Max, says, "Now weren\'t I the bozo on this bus!" - a reference to the 1971 album by The Firesign Theatre called "I Think We\'re All Bozos on this Bus". A reference like this may seem against period, but Martin Scorsese, like the Firesign Theatre players, was part of the counter-culture scene of the \'60s and early \'70s. Considered with other elements in the script, such as the lax attitude toward marijuana, this doesn\'t seem so out of character.', u'Jessica Lange accepted her role to work with Robert De Niro and Martin Scorsese.', u'David Johansen was considered for the role of Max Cady.', u'The opening of the movie is very similar to the opening of Hitchcock\'s "Vertigo" both visually (the red/black fade of female face) and musically (Elmer Bernstein emulating Bernard Hermann\'s original score).', u'When Max Cady tells Bowden to "check out the Bible, Councilor, the Book between Esther and Psalms," he\'s referring to the Book of Job. This is its placement in the Christian Bible. In the original Hebrew Bible, the Book of Job is in between Proverbs and Song of Songs, the latter being the first of the Five Megillot (Scrolls).', u'Shannen Doherty, Nicole Eggert, Bridget Fonda, Jodie Foster, Helen Hunt, Diane Lane, Demi Moore, Molly Ringwald, Meg Ryan, Winona Ryder, Brooke Shields and Tiffani Thiessen were considered for Danielle Bowden.', u'Nicole Eggert auditioned for the role of Danielle but turned it down.', u'Lori Davis (Illeana Douglas) was named after Lori Martin, who played Nancy Bowden in Cape Fear (1962).', u'Sole collaboration between longtime friends and New Hollywood trailblazers Martin Scorsese and Steven Spielberg. Spielberg oversaw development of the project via Amblin Entertainment, although he is uncredited on the film itself.', u"Another music video shown on Danielle's TV is The Bog, of the band Bigod 20.", u'Sam Bowden and Max Cady are the only characters to retain the same names from Cape Fear (1962).', u"The film was released two days before Martin Scorsese's 49th birthday.", u'Fangoria magazine was barred from covering the film because Universal, Steven Spielberg, and Martin Scorsese saw the film as a thriller, not a horror film. They were also barred from covering The Silence of the Lambs (1991) for similar reasons.', u'A picture of James Dean is shown when Danielle (Juliette Lewis) slams the door while her parents argue.', u"The note that is broken on Nick Nolte's grand piano is an A two octaves above middle C.", u'Robert Mitchum as the Southern policeman Lieut. Elgart casually says of Cady, "If he\'s unemployed, he gotta have money, or we\'ll bust him for vagrancy." Mitchum was himself charged with vagrancy in Savannah as a young man.', u'Both the 1962 and 1991 film adaptations of Cape Fear, formerly titled "The Executioners", omit Sam Bowden\'s two young sons Jamie and Bucky.', u'Martin Scorsese: [mother] fruit stand customer.', u'When Cady strangles Kersek with the piano wire, Steven Spielberg suggested he be dressed up as the housekeeper while doing it.', u"Robert De Niro would only get under the Bowdens' car if a stuntman could prove it could be done.", u"During Cady's death scene, he seems to be talking gibberish. He's actually speaking in tongues, elated at the fact that he thinks he's ascending to Heaven.", u'Body count: 5 (including the dog).']
release_dates: [u'USA::15 November 1991', u'Japan::21 December 1991', u'Australia::9 January 1992', u'Germany::21 February 1992 (Berlin International Film Festival)', u'Argentina::27 February 1992', u'Germany::27 February 1992', u'Finland::28 February 1992', u'Belgium::March 1992 (Brussels International Festival of Fantasy Films)', u'Italy::4 March 1992', u'Norway::5 March 1992', u'Denmark::6 March 1992', u'UK::6 March 1992', u'Greece::6 March 1992', u'Portugal::6 March 1992', u'Sweden::6 March 1992', u'Spain::11 March 1992', u'Netherlands::13 March 1992', u'France::18 March 1992', u'Brazil::27 March 1992', u'Hungary::3 April 1992', u'Ireland::3 April 1992', u'France::October 1997 (Montpellier Mediterranean Film Festival)', u'France::21 October 2015 (re-release)']

title: Back to the Future
plot_outline: The time travelling adventures of Doc Brown, his family, and his friend, Marty McFly.
keywords: [u'time-traveller', u'backwards-time-travel', u'pet-dog', u'four-word-title', u'back-to-the-future', u'intergenerational-friendship', u'teenage-boy', u'mad-scientist', u'2d-animation', u'surrealism', u'cult-tv', u'spin-off', u'spin-off-from-cult-film', u'spin-off-from-cult-favorite', u'car', u'teenage-hero', u'delorean-dmc-12', u'based-on-cult-favorite', u'inventor', u'scientist', u'kid', u'time-travel', u'based-on-film']
taglines: [u"It looks like we don't have any Taglines for this title yet."]
trivia: [u'In season one, episode two, "A Family Vacation", Harold McFly (Marty\'s ancestor in the Middle Ages) and his love, Jennivere, decide to move to Ireland "to raise generations of McFlys". The family stays in Ireland until the 1880s, when Seamus and Maggie McFly move to Hill Valley in Back to the Future Part III (1990).', u'Despite being major characters in the Back to the Future trilogy, neither George nor Lorraine McFly ever appear in the series.', u'While, out of the entire cast of all three movies, only Mary Steenburgen (Clara) and Thomas F. Wilson (Biff) reprise their roles in the animated portion of the show, Christopher Lloyd appeared as Doc Brown in live-action bumpers (the parts between the show and the commercials) and in a live-action segment at the end of each episode with Bill Nye, teaching kids about science.', u'In season one, episode one, "Brothers", Marty mentions Dean Strickland. Mr. Strickland from the first two movies, is now Dean of Hill Valley college.', u'In season two, episode nine, "Hill Valley Brown-Out", one of the films playing at the theater is Back to the Future (1985).', u"There were plans for a character named Polly Clayton to appear in the series. Polly, aged nine, would presumably have been a relation of Clara's, but the character was dropped before the series aired.", u'The theme song was "Back In Time", which was performed by Huey Lewis & The News at the end of the first film. However, the version used in the series was not sung by the group.', u'Marty\'s middle name is revealed to be "Seamus" in the series. He was named after Seamus McFly from Back to the Future Part III (1990).', u'In season two, episode eight, "A Verne by Any Other Name", Verne tries persuading Jules Verne to change his name to Bart Simpson, so that Doc and Clara will not end up naming him after the author. Dan Castellaneta, the voice of the animated Doc on this show, voices Bart\'s father Homer in The Simpsons (1989).', u'There are numerous references to Garfield and Friends (1988) in several episodes, which also aired on Saturday mornings on CBS.', u'Doc\'s middle name is revealed to be "Lathrop" in the series. An early draft of Back to the Future Part III (1990) had a scene where, in 1885, Doc met a young girl named Sarah Lathrop, who would eventually become his mother.']
release_dates: [u'USA::14 September 1991', u'USA::21 September 1991']

taglines: [u'Eight legs, two fangs and an attitude.', u'The suspense of Alien! The excitement of Jaws! The fun of Back To The Future!']
trivia: [u'The small spiders used in the film were Avondale spiders (Delena Cancerides), a harmless species from New Zealand that were provided by Landcare Research in Auckland. Despite their fierce appearance, this spider is docile member of the crab-spider family and are, in fact, harmless to humans. They were not allowed back in New Zealand for quarantine reasons. The giant "spider" used in the film was a species of a bird-eating tarantula, which attains an 8" legspan or more. Those types of tarantula are not easy to handle and can give a nasty bite. The spiders in the film were managed and handled by famed entomologist Steven R. Kutcher.', u"The animatronic General Spider seen at the film's climax was one of the earliest prop jobs done by Mythbusters' Jamie Hyneman.", u'The sound of a spider being crushed by John Goodman was made by the foley artists crushing a couple of potato chips', u"The first film released under Disney's Hollywood Pictures label, which was also created so the studio could release more adult-oriented fare.", u"Canaima is the name of the avenging spirit of the Guyana Indians. It's also the name the area in Venezuela where the beginning of the movie was filmed and home to the world's tallest waterfall, Angel Falls.", u'The movie was filmed in Cambria, California. All the school scenes were filmed at Coast Union High School.', u'The production team painted purple stripes on the back of \'Big Bob\' and added a prosthetic abdomen "to give him greater bulk".', u'When in the cemetery exhuming one of the bodies, the name of the grave in the background says MacNamara, which is also the surname of the actor Brian, playing Chris Collins.', u"In the film the species of spider are Eusocial (Division of labour, division of reproductive labour, overlapping adult generations and cooperative brood care) but in reality most species of spider are solitary and aggressive to other spiders. The social species just live communally and don't show all the traits of Eusociality."]

taglines: [u'Take Your Batch to See the New Batch.', u'Here they grow again.', u"We warned you. Remember the rules. You didn't listen."]
trivia: [u'The uplifting end of the world video scene was included by the filmmakers when they find out that one of the news networks actually have such a video prepare to run in case of the end of the world. This video apparently still exists and still ready to run at the final hour.', u'In a deleted scene, the Gremlins release all the animals in the "Splice o\' Life" lab. During the filming of this scene, the monkeys in the lab set were genuinely so terrified of the Gremlin puppets, that they refused to leave their cages when their trainers called for them.', u'The filmmakers chose John Rambo as the character that Gizmo was going to imitate in this movie. The permission for their use was granted by Sylvester Stallone.', u"At one point in the film, Joe Dante attempted to involve his audience in the story by making it seem as if the gremlins had taken over whatever theatre Gremlins 2 would be screened in. This sequence was inspired by a similar stunt in William Castle's The Tingler (1959). During his DVD commentary for this movie, Dante recalled that Warner Bros. wanted the sequence cut, as they were concerned the audience would believe the film actually had malfunctioned; test screening ultimately proved otherwise. However, the video version caused problems: Instead of film-breaking effects, the scene looked like a VHS malfunctioning. Many rental copies were returned as a result of this, and video mastering houses called the filmmakers to ask them if this was intentional.", u'When Christopher Lee was cast in this movie, one of the first things he did was apologize to Joe Dante (who also directed The Howling (1981)) for appearing in Howling II: ... Your Sister Is a Werewolf (1985).', u'The opening aerial shot of New York City was stock footage from Superman IV: The Quest for Peace (1987).', u'Unlike the "PG" rated predecessor, the MPAA rated this movie "PG-13". It should be noted that Gremlins (1984) is one of the movies that helped to create the PG-13 rating.', u'In the cartoon intro, Daffy Duck says to Bugs: "Fifty years of you hogging the spotlight is enough". This movie was released the year of Bugs Bunny\'s 50th birthday.', u'Leonard Maltin appears as himself repeating his criticisms of Gremlins (1984) while he holds a video version of the movie. However, his rant is cut short when gremlins pounce on him as a result. In his annual Movie Guide he gives Gremlins 2 three stars (out of a possible four) and refers to this scene as a "gratuitous cameo", though he doesn\'t say he\'s actually in the movie.', u"The mother scolding the theater manager regarding the movie's inappropriate tone for children was based in fact. During a screening of Gremlins (1984), Joe Dante really was excoriated by a mother who walked out of the theater with her daughter during the infamous kitchen massacre sequence. The daughter begged to be let back in the theater, got free from the mother, and hid in the theater to watch the rest of the film.", u'Originally, Steven Spielberg wanted to cut the scene when a boy crosses the "Police Line" banner outside Clamp Tower. He changed his mind when Joe Dante revealed to him that this boy was his nephew.', u'Mowhawk is a recreation of Stripe from the first film and is voiced by the same actor.', u'The movie that Grandpa Fred presents in his show as "The Attack of the Octopus People" is, in fact, Octaman (1971), which feature the first costume designed by Rick Baker.', u'In the original script, Randall Peltzer was to return after the gremlins were killed at the end, and give to Gizmo his newest "invention": a wet-suit like thing that would prevent Gizmo from ever getting wet again, therefore preventing any sort of gremlin problems in the future (provided it never ate after midnight). The scene was all set to shoot, and the actor who played Mr. Peltzer, Hoyt Axton, was available to shoot the scene. But, the filmmakers figured that the movie was already running too long, and they\'d never use the scene anyway, so it was never shot.', u'Joe Dante told Cahiers du Cin\xe9ma in 1990, that Warner Bros. opened this movie directly opposite Dick Tracy (1990) in an attempt to keep the box-office record set by Batman (1989) from being broken.', u'Aside from Mohawk, the other three Mogwai created from Gizmo are called George, Lenny, and Daffy (the first two referring to John Steinbeck\'s novel "Of Mice And Men", the latter referring to Daffy Duck).', u"The character of Grandpa Fred is obviously based on Al Lewis's character (Grandpa Munster) in the television series The Munsters (1964).", u"After Gremlins (1984) became such a surprise success, Warner Bros. immediately wanted a sequel, but director Joe Dante had had enough Gremlins for a while and declined. Work on Gremlins 2 proceeded without him, as the studio approached various directors and writers. Storylines considered included sending the gremlins to cities like Las Vegas or even the planet Mars. After these ideas fell through, the studio finally asked Dante again, who agreed on the condition that he be allowed to do anything he wanted. He also received a bigger budget. In the DVD commentaries for both the original film and the sequel, Dante stated that he felt that Gremlins 2 was a case of waiting too long to capitalize on the success of the original, which hurt the sequel's chances of success.", u'For the special effects, Joe Dante turned to Rick Baker when Chris Walas and Rob Bottin had to turn it down. Initially, Baker was not interested as he saw this movie as too much work for a project in which he would not be the creator but rather a successor to Walas. He was eventually persuaded to accept the job when it was suggested he could make the Gremlins and Mogwai more diverse.', u'The face of one of the Gremlins, the one who turns on the microwave during the cooking segment, is modeled after The Kraken, from "Clash of the Titans" (1981).', u"When Billy is trying to explain the rules regarding the mogwai to Forster's staff, they find them quite absurd and interrogate him on the application of this rules. This scene originates from the fact that the filmmakers themselves saw the rules as irrational, and some questions in the scene were based upon queries raised by fans of Gremlins (1984).", u'In the scene where Mohawk drinks a potion which enables him to change into a centauroid spider, the pulsating sound effect from Tarantula (1955) can be heard. The effect was originally recorded for the Martian war machines in The War of the Worlds (1953).', u"There is a sample of the action music from the film The 'Burbs (1989), also directed by Joe Dante and composed by Jerry Goldsmith, when the Bat Gremlin flies out of the Clamp Tower after being injected with the sunblock solution.", u'The movie that the gremlins George and Lenny are watching in the systems control center is The Beast from 20,000 Fathoms (1953).', u'Chris Walas, who created the Gremlins in the first film, declined the opportunity to create them again, choosing instead to create the effects for and direct The Fly II (1989).', u'When Gizmo first sees the janitor, played by John Astin, he says "Gomez," referring to The Addams Family (1964) character made famous by Astin.', u'Joe Dante prefers this film to the original.', u"When Gremlins 2 made its debut on home video, the filmmakers altered the film-breaking scene, to make it seem as if VCRs had been broken by the gremlins. This time actor John Wayne (in footage from Chisum (1970) forces the gremlins into continuing the film, although voice impersonation was needed since Wayne had been dead since 1979. Wayne's son, Michael Wayne, recommended Chad Everett for the voice. Notably, a clip from Falling Hare (1943), featuring Bugs Bunny and a different, cartoon gremlin, appears in this version.", u'Gizmo refers to Mr. Wing as "Keye Luke", which is, of course, the actor\'s real name.', u'In a corridor of the Clamp Tower, one nameplate says "Vectorscope Labs". This is a reference to the movie Innerspace (1987) also directed by Joe Dante.', u'Robert Picardo controlled Greta, the "female" gremlin when it was attached to him instead of the puppeteers because the puppet had so much contact and movements with his character. This technique is also used in the scene where Daniel Clamp (John Glover) pushes the gremlin in the paper shredder.', u'The scene where Gizmo dances to "I\'m Ready" by Fats Domino was originally supposed to feature "Dancing With Myself" by Billy Idol. The filmmakers were unable to get permission to use the Idol song, so they found another song with the same beat.', u"Among the changes in the original script was that Daniel Clamp (John Glover) evolved from being the central villain into kind of a nice guy, while the character played by Robert Picardo took over most of the villain's role.", u'In a deleted scene, three of the main gremlins (George, Lenny and Daffy) sneaking into Grandpa Fred\'s studio and "help" him host, which worked because Grandpa Fred\'s show was supposed to be scary. A still from this scene was used on the video cover.', u'Most of the scenes where Gizmo (or the other mogwai) were on their own, were filmed with double scale puppets.', u'For the Italian version of the movie, notorious Italian art critic Vittorio Sgarbi gave his voice to the Brain Gremlin.', u"Several gremlins hiccuping are archive recordings of Mel Blanc's hiccups from various Looney Tunes shorts.", u'Chuck Jones was lured out of retirement to provide the cartoon segment in the film.', u'Tim Curry was considered for the voice of the Brain Gremlin.', u'The character Daniel Clamp is obviously a caricature of real estate mogul and Republican president-elect Donald Trump.', u'Immediately after Billy electrocutes the gremlins in the lobby, a musical quote from the "Dies Irae" (a Latin hymn about the Judgment Day) can be heard in the musical score.', u'WILHELM SCREAM: As a victim is covered in gremlins and he falls off of a ledge.', u'At one point, Joe Dante, Michael Finnell, Steven Spielberg and Charles S. Haas thought what the movie needed was some kind of SWAT team character, a soldier of fortune who could come in during the fourth act, and there would be a lot of Road Runner-Coyote gags between this guy and the Gremlins. Charles Napier was their first choice for this character.', u'The original version of the film was longer, but, Steven Spielberg after the first screening claimed there were too many gremlins and several scenes were cut as a result.', u'As the Bat Gremlin crashes through the wall, escaping into the city, it leaves a hole in the shape of the Batman symbol.', u"When Kate arrives to Billy's office looking for Gizmo, she finds mogwai Daffy on the top of the Clamp Tower model playing with some airplane toys located over him. This is an homage to King Kong (1933).", u"Clamp's automatic office doors open and sound the same as the doors of the Enterprise from Star Trek (1966).", u'In a deleted scene, Dr. Catheter examines a bat injected with the sunblock solution. He then says to Wally, "I\'m told they sometimes feed on blood"; this is a reference to Christopher Lee\'s performances as Count Dracula in the "Hammer" Horror films.', u'Chris Columbus was unavailable to write the script due to him directing Home Alone (1990).', u'In a corridor of the Clamp Tower, one nameplate says "Dr. Quatermass". Quatermass is the main character in a number of British television series and movies, including The Quatermass Experiment (1953).', u'Joe Dante claimed that the gremlins musical number is a shameless steal from the film Dames (1934), another Warner Bros. release.', u'Ranked #33 in Empire Magazine\'s "50 Greatest Ever Movie Sequels" (2009).', u'The film is bookended by animated segments featuring Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck. 13 years later Joe Dante would feature those characters as the leads in Looney Tunes: Taas kehiss\xe4 (2003).', u"By the time of the film's theatrical release in June of 1990, despite wearing the WWF Championship belt in his brief cameo, Hulk Hogan was no longer the reigning champion.", u'In the scene where they go to the Canadian restaurant, the phrase "Gretzky Party of 6, Eh" can be heard on the restaurants intercom system, a reference to famous Canadian hockey player Wayne Gretzky and Canadians penchant for using the phrase "eh" at the end of their sentences.', u'With the intervening advancements in special effects technology from the first film, the gremlins are much more animated in this sequel and are seen walking and dancing.', u'Suggested by Jonathan Kaplan, Joe Dante hired Charles S. Haas to write the screenplay.', u'There\'s a scene where a voice says "You know, I\'ve been thinking, Mr. Clamp would make a great president".This scene didn\'t make it to the final cut but it appears as a deleted scene in the Blu-ray and DVD editions.', u'Kenneth Tobey (Projectionist) and Christopher Lee (Doctor Catheter) both starred in film adaptations of John W. Campbell Jr.\'s 1938 novella "Who Goes There?": Toey played Captain Patrick Hendry in The Thing from Another World (1951) while Lee played Professor Sir Alexander Saxton in Horror Express (1972).', u'A billboard of Do the Right Thing (1989) can be seen in the scene in Times Square, next to Burger King.', u'After Innerspace (1987), this movie marked the fourth collaboration between Joe Dante and Michael Finnell with Steven Spielberg.', u'John Hora, the Director of Photography (who made his screen acting debut on Innerspace (1987), also directed by Joe Dante), appears briefly in the movie, but his scene was cut.', u"Christopher Lee went on to appear with John Astin's son Sean Astin and granddaughter Ali Astin in the Lord of the Rings films. They did not, however, share any scenes together.", u'The same year, Robert Picardo did voice work on the Arnold Schwarzenegger science fiction action thriller Total Recall (1990), which he provide the voice of Johnny Cab.', u'The 31st most successful film of 1990 (as opposed to the first film which ranked number 4 in the year-end charts for 1984).', u"John Astin's son Sean Astin had appeared in The Goonies (1985), also produced by Steven Spielberg. The original Gremlins (1984) featured another Goonie, Corey Feldman, and was also written by Chris Columbus.", u'Novelisation by David Bischoff.', u"Jerry Goldsmith's final cameo appearance in a motion picture.", u'In the novelization for Young Sherlock Holmes (1985), the inventor Waxflatter hallucinates gremlins sabotaging his ornithopter, which is a definite in-joke to Gremlins (1984); both films and Gremlins 2 were produced by Steven Spielberg.', u'Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck appeared at the beginning of the film and again during the end credits.', u'The end credits state that the song "Bombers In The Sky" by The Thompson Twins is used in the film. More accurately, a snippet of the "Razorback! Mix" of this song can be heard when the Mogwai are seen hiding under a table at the Frozen Yogurt stand. The music heard here is not part of the single version of \'Bombers In The Sky\', meaning listeners only familiar with the original will not recognize it as such.', u"This film is about gremlins taking over a building and in one scene, Gizmo imitates John Rambo. Sylvester Stallone whom played John Rambo in First Blood (1982) and it's sequels, passed on the role of John McClane in Die Hard (1988). That film was about a building that is taken over by terrorists.", u"Scenes from A Wonderful Life can be seen on one of the screens in Clamp's office.", u'Gremlins 2: The New Batch became the 2nd Steven Spielberg project to involve the Looney Tunes character. The 1st being is Who Framed Roger Rabbit, and the 3rd being is Tiny Toons.', u'The scene where the organ playing phantom Gremlin is unmasked, is an exact scene from Phantom of the Opera (1925),', u'John Astin: as the janitor, who tries to repair the water fountain.', u'Hulk Hogan: As himself (in the original theatrical release).', u'Henry Gibson: as the employee fired by Forster, for taking an unauthorized break.', u'Bubba Smith: as Himself, trying to save Dick Butkus who is attacked at the salad bar.', u'Jason Presson: Alex, the yogurt jerk.', u"Charles S. Haas: (The screenwriter) as Casper, Dr. Catheter's assistant.", u'Jerry Goldsmith: alongside his wife Carol Heather Goldsmith, as customers at the frozen yogurt counter.', u'Leonard Maltin: as himself giving a review for Gremlins (1984).', u'Julia Sweeney: as Peggy, the "Splice o\' Life" lab receptionist.', u"Joe Dante: As the director of Grandpa Fred's show. Also the voice of Microwave Marge's director.", u'Joe Dante: [Looney Tunes Sound Effects] Sound effects lifted from classic Warner Bros. cartoons are used frequently throughout the film.', u'At one point, one of the ideas for the ending of the movie was that the gremlins were supposed to be killed by Daniel Clamp filling the building up with cement. That was until the animators discovered that they had the technology to create an "electrical" Gremlin, which they realized could improve the storyline (and its ending).', u'The composer of this film, Jerry Goldsmith, also wrote the music for Rambo: First Blood, part II. In this film John Rambo claims, "to survive a war, you gotta become war." These words inspire Gizmo to stand up against Mowhawk.']
release_dates: [u'USA::15 June 1990', u'Norway::5 July 1990', u'Finland::6 July 1990', u'Taiwan::7 July 1990', u'Uruguay::9 July 1990', u'Colombia::12 July 1990', u'Italy::13 July 1990', u'Sweden::13 July 1990', u'Netherlands::20 July 1990', u'Denmark::27 July 1990', u'Spain::27 July 1990', u'UK::27 July 1990', u'Ireland::27 July 1990', u'Japan::3 August 1990', u'Argentina::9 August 1990', u'Portugal::17 August 1990', u'France::22 August 1990', u'West Germany::23 August 1990', u'Turkey::14 September 1990', u'Australia::20 September 1990', u'Hong Kong::20 September 1990', u'Brazil::28 September 1990', u'Hungary::11 October 1990', u'Greece::16 October 1990', u'Peru::25 December 1990', u'Poland::25 January 1991', u'South Korea::24 August 1991', u'Australia::31 July 2010 (Melbourne International Film Festival)', u'Ireland::25 October 2010 (Dublin Horrorthon Film Festival)', u'USA::10 November 2012 (St. Louis International Film Festival)', u'Spain::2 August 2015 (Barcelona) (re-release)']

title: Roller Coaster Rabbit
plot_outline: Roger Rabbit struggles to keep wandering Baby Herman safe in an amusement park where the usual havoc ensues.
taglines: [u"It looks like we don't have any Taglines for this title yet."]
trivia: [u'Originally a special in-joke was planned. It was to have taken place when Roger and Baby Herman reached the top of the roller coaster\'s ridiculously high first lift hill. At the top would have been a crossroads with a traffic light that turned red, pausing the pair\'s car. At this point, the "Long Car" was have zoomed through the intersection in front of them. Riding in this roller coaster train was supposed to have been every single animated character that has ever appeared in a Disney film. Mickey and Minnie were to have been seated in the front car, while Monstro the Whale from Pinocchio (1940) would have been towering over everyone from his seat at the very back of the train. Disney animators worked for weeks to get this brief flash of a scene just right. Ancient model sheets pulled from the studio\'s animation research library, to make sure every single character looked perfect. Where each character should go on the train was endlessly debated. However, despite all the effort put into the gag, it had to eventually be cut. If the "Long Car" zoomed through the scene as fast as it was originally supposed to, none of the audience would have been able to recognize any of the characters. But if it was slowed down, it threw off the frantic pace of the rest of the short. So the joke was left on the cutting room floor.', u'This animated short was the center of some disputes. Michael Eisner wanted to shown before Dick Tracy (1990) and Steven Spielberg wanted to shown before Arachnophobia (1990). The short ended up shown with Dick Tracy.', u'This animated short was re-issued in front of Toy Story (1995) in the USA to take the place of a canceled Roger Rabbit short intended to be shown before that movie.', u'Was released theatrically with Dick Tracy (1990).', u'This animated short can be found on the Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988) Vista Series DVD, released in 2003.', u'Out of the three Roger Rabbit shorts, this is the only one that was released by Disney\'s affiliate studio Touchstone Pictures. The other two shorts ("Tummy Trouble" and "Trail Mix-Up") were released directly under Walt Disney Pictures.', u"This is the Only Roger Rabbit short to receive a PG Rating, due to the scene with The Bull where Baby Herman pulls at the Bull's scrotum, thinking it's a Balloon."]
release_dates: [u'USA::15 June 1990', u'Ireland::6 July 1990', u'Colombia::12 July 1990', u'Spain::30 July 1990', u'USA::22 November 1995 (re-release)', u'UK::22 March 1996']

title: Back to the Future Part III
plot_outline: Enjoying a peaceable existence in 1885, Doctor Emmet Brown is about to be killed by Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen. Marty McFly travels back in time to save his friend.
